If you do turn to Page 9 in our financial supplement, you will see that there is one cut of our $31.6 trillion of assets under custody, and we described $18 billion of those being equity-based. So I think that's a good indication in the custodial side. And then on the asset management side, we also do the equity cut on Page 10. So it's significant. It's in the -- you can see it's in the 55, 60, 60-ish percentage range, and so we are somewhat dependent on equity market. I think that's why in good times, we need -- we're going to be able to benefit from that, but we also need to make sure that we are heavily -- that we're always careful on expenses and create that scalable cost base so that we don't actually add too many costs in good time so that we can navigate through. But it's certainly part of our business model.

speaker.position: RBC Capital Markets, LLC, Research Division

followQuestion.speaker: Gerard S. CassidyVery good. And then to follow up, I think, Ron, you touched on the pricing headwinds historically or maybe, Eric, you brought up that 1.5% to 2% was something that was common. But it looked like in 2018, it bumped up to 4%. You're looking for something similar in 2019. What's driving that? Is it competitors are just being much more aggressive, and they're willing to price products maybe leading a loss, and it's just a way of getting the business and maybe cross-selling other products? But what do you think has driven it up to doubling of what it used to be?

followAnswer.speaker: Ronald Philip O’HanleyGerard, I think it's what we said earlier. The amount of hurt these clients are under is quite high of the typical asset manager, whether you're large, medium or small. So there's just inordinate pressure coming from the client base would be number one. Number two, this assumption, particularly when you're pricing an asset management client, that there'll be both market and fees that will over time actually make what looks like an entry-level price -- takes an entry-level price that may look like it's too thin, kind of make it fuller over time as flows and market help out. When that assumption goes away, it just lays bare that the price that you had as an initial price on a sustained basis in fact isn't sustainable. So at least for us, can't speak for obviously the rest of the industry, it has caused us to be much more careful about how we think about this, that in addition to getting more term so that pricing can't change overnight, looking at what other products, and as Eric talked about earlier, the product stack as you move up from custody becomes -- it tends to be -- it's not price-insensitive but less and less price-sensitive or less and less commodity-like, if you will. And looking hard at deposits and then as importantly making sure that we try and get another part of the wallet or some consolidation out of it. And in most cases, we're getting some or all of those kinds of things.

trainsition.speaker: OperatorYour next question comes from the line of Steven Chubak with Wolfe Research.

question.speaker: Steven Joseph ChubakSo wanted to ask a follow-up question on capital return. Last year on CCAR, you were about 50 basis points short on that stress tier 1 leverage target. Your capital ratios are flat year-on-year. Eric, you gave a lot of really helpful color talking about the actions you've taken to improve your CCAR standing. What I'm wondering is if the Fed stress test assumptions are similar to last year, what gives you that confidence that you can achieve an 80% payout target? Is that -- should we view that more as a medium-term target? Or do you think you can get there in the upcoming test?

answer.speaker: Eric Walter AboafIt's Eric. We're optimistic about this upcoming test. We're -- there's no certainty on it, but we are optimistic. I think we're optimistic for 2 reasons that we have under control, and then there's one that we don't, right. The 2 that we do have are -- under our control are, number one, the shape of the investment portfolio. And if you remember, we made adjustments in the first quarter of last year, where we saw the results and how those play through into CCAR so we had a good understanding of the kind of the change this and then results in that. And then we made some more adjustments the fourth quarter of this year based on some of those learnings and the other 6 data points we've had over the last year. The second one is because of the play we've now better understood the counterparty stress test that the Fed runs, right, we've actively intervened in terms of how we actually structure and limit our counterparty exposures across our businesses, whether that's in FX, whether that's in securities lending. And so we've made very conscious choices, some of which have impacted revenue, and you've seen that in particular in sec lending, to actually adjust our exposure levels. Now we're trying to transact with our best clients as much as we used to before. But in some cases, we've had to be more calibrated. So we have literally -- if we -- if you were to go down to the trading floor and the risk management team, they literally had new parameters that they've installed that we've been operating at since the -- since late summer and early fall. So both of those give us some confidence that we can -- that we should be able to do better this year. The obvious unknown is the test itself, right. There's the macroeconomic shop, what's in that? There is the global market trading bookshop, which has the counterparty piece to it. And then it's everything else in the test, including assumption for balance sheet growth and so forth. And on those areas, we don't have any new information, obviously won't until we see some of that in late this month, early next month, and then we see the test come through in June.

followQuestion.speaker: Steven Joseph ChubakGot it. And just one more follow-up for me on capital optimization efforts. You continue to have a significant amount of preferred in your capital stack, certainly well in excess of many of your GCIB peers. I was hoping you could speak to your capacity or appetite to maybe redeem some of those preferreds and how we could possibly think about the timing of redemptions and the associated savings.

followAnswer.speaker: Eric Walter AboafYes, I think the way I would describe the capital stack is that capital stack is proportioned relative to how the current rules are written and implemented through CCAR, where leverage ratios matter. And so there's obviously an importance of having prefs in the stack. If that were to change, we'd obviously reconsider, and so that would give us an opportunity to call or to adjust the alternative Tier 1 component, which is the prefs. I do think, though, as we go into CCAR, our first priority is return capital to our common equity holders, right. We're quite conscious of the -- of some of our deal activity and our issuances this past year, and we feel like the first priority is to get capital back to our common equity holders as we go through the CCAR process this year.

followQuestion.speaker: Steven Joseph ChubakAnd just one quick follow-up relating to that common equity remark. Just given the Fed's willingness to greenlight payouts north of 100%, the fact that they've clearly indicated that they're loathe to have this binary Pascal outcome, given the confidence level that you have in all the changes that you've made to reposition yourself ahead of CCAR, would you actually look in the near term, maybe exceed that 80% in order to more aggressively mitigate the dilution impact from CRD?

followAnswer.speaker: Eric Walter AboafWe have said that we'd like to, and we're optimistic that we can do better than 80% so that's exactly the intention and hope that we have. And I'll just be clear that there's some of both that's necessary for that, but that is what we'd like to be able to deliver this year, and we believe we've made some of the adjustments necessary at our end of the -- that are under our own control to effectuate that. So we're -- we'd like to be able to deliver on that. That would be our intention, given what we've -- how we're proceeding.

trainsition.speaker: OperatorYour next question comes from the line of Geoffrey Elliott with Autonomous.

question.speaker: Geoffrey ElliottOn the income guide, just to be clear, first of all, the 3% to 4% down points to about $2.2 billion. And then annualizing that, we kind of get to an annual run rate of about 8.8 if that was sustained. Is that right?

answer.speaker: Eric Walter AboafYes, it's Eric. That's right. I mean, that's -- we're trying to start with where we are today, and we're trying to adjust for the markets, the flows, the limited amount of client transaction activity. And then you have the lumpiness from trading from 4Q to 1Q, right. So we're -- we always want to be careful and appropriately conservative there. And then there's just the 606 effects of Charles River. So we've tried to factor all that into our estimate. And then we've said that that's a good run rate for several quarters. We'd like that to be just a quarter or 2, not very long, but we're trying to be careful here. And to be honest, we're trying to be careful about revenues because we think if we're doing that, then we're going to be even more effective and adroit at interventions on expenses, and we think that's what we should demand of ourselves and what you would all expect of us. I think the scenarios on revenue though are very wide, to be honest, because there is the range of different market assumptions, flow assumptions and underlying transaction activity. We just have some -- we just have a little more visibility into the first quarter, including the usual adjustments on market flows, macroeconomics and a little bit of pricing, which tends to be a little deeper in the first quarter than the out quarters, just the way the calendar works, and so we're just trying to factor that in. But off of that base, I think there's a range of scenarios, and we'd obviously like to see more positive ones. And if we see those, we will -- we've got a set of conference schedule set up in February and March and in May, where we'll certainly update for changes.

followQuestion.speaker: Geoffrey ElliottGot it. But it sounds like in the sort of market assumptions that you're showing on Slide 16, that could be a run rate that sticks around for a couple of quarters. Is that fair? I just want to make sure that we're understanding it right.

followAnswer.speaker: Eric Walter AboafYes. That could be the case, and that's what we're calibrating our expense work to.

trainsition.speaker: OperatorYour next question comes from the line of Vivek Juneja with Morgan Stanley -- sorry, JP Morgan.

speaker.position: JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division

question.speaker: Vivek JunejaThis is Vivek. A couple of questions for you folks. Firstly, Eric, on CRD, the operating margin obviously in Q4, because of ASC 606 just a little bit inflated, what -- on a full year basis, what would you guide us to as a sort of a more normalized operating margin before you put in any cost savings or anything else?

answer.speaker: Eric Walter AboafVivek, I think we disclosed back in July an operating margin for that business at around 50% on the old ASC numbers in a live basis. I think the way the current year adjusts a bit, you might get for -- going from 605 to 606, just given the pattern of how they've done the accounting historically versus now, you get a small uptick in margin from there. I think then the modeling becomes -- has probably 2 facets going in. One is the investments that we're making in the business and then the revenue ramp-up relative to those investments. And that, that will tend to trend the margin rate down a bit as we -- in the early year or 2 of building the business.

speaker.position: JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division

followQuestion.speaker: Vivek JunejaOkay. All right. Good. Because while -- you cautioned us on annualizing the revenues and presuming the cost we can annualize if we are modeling out CRD separately, right?

followAnswer.speaker: Eric Walter AboafYes.

speaker.position: JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division

followQuestion.speaker: Vivek JunejaYes, okay. Different question, you called out in your NIM onetime benefits from hedging activities. Can you quantify that? And how much of that in the fourth quarter?

followAnswer.speaker: Eric Walter AboafYes. In the fourth quarter, it was about $6 million roughly, and a little bit comes from some of the dislocation [ the -- up front being ] swap market. We've taken our swap positions down over the years, as you know, but there's always some dislocations towards the -- over the holiday season, in particular towards the end of the quarter. So we saw a little bit of that, and it was a positive dislocation because of how the currencies between euro and some of -- and yen actually played through, so that was a positive. And then on long-term debt, you get a little bit of this mark-to-market adjustment in the underlying accounting as you got rates and credit spreads move a little bit. So and about [ $6 ], and it'll just -- which won't reappear in the first quarter.

speaker.position: JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division

followQuestion.speaker: Vivek JunejaCan I sneak in another one? Which was you combined an accounting with FX and brokerage, I know a lot of -- a part of brokerage used to have electronic FX trading. What -- the rest of it, things like transition management, have they just diminished through a smaller base or has something else changed?

followAnswer.speaker: Eric Walter AboafNo, I think what we're trying to do is literally simplify the disclosure. And if we did something that took helpful materials away, we can certainly revisit. But we had a line that was historically called total trading services, which is both our direct foreign exchange trading plus our, what I'll call electronic foreign exchange venues, those were in what was called brokerage, and then some of the other kind of fund connect, like our money market electronic venue, a little bit of transition management and a few other smaller items like portfolio solutions. So we've just -- I think we labeled that total FX trading services just to give it the kind of the description that's appropriate. I think within that, I'm just scanning through, about 80% of those revenues are foreign exchange-related. The rest tend to be a little bit of the money market or portfolio solutions-type activity.

ending.speaker: OperatorAnd there are no further questions at this time. This concludes today's call, and we thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.
